content: Chose PostgreSQL over MongoDB for user data because we need ACID transactions for payment processing and the schema is relatively stable.
Implemented Redis caching layer in front of product catalog API. Cache TTL set to 5 minutes, reduced database load by 73% during peak traffic.
Split monolith into microservices using domain-driven design boundaries. Started with extracting the notification service since it had clear interfaces and no complex dependencies.
Adopted gRPC for internal service communication instead of REST because of better performance with binary serialization and strong typing with Protocol Buffers.
Switched from SQS to Kafka for event streaming to support multiple consumers replaying events and maintain ordering guarantees within partitions.
Using blue-green deployment strategy for production releases to enable instant rollback and zero-downtime deployments.
Implemented circuit breaker pattern with Hystrix for third-party payment gateway calls. Set failure threshold to 50% over 10 requests with 30-second timeout.
Chose DynamoDB for session storage due to single-digit millisecond latency requirements and built-in auto-scaling capabilities.
Adopted GraphQL for mobile API to reduce over-fetching and number of round trips. REST endpoints remain for legacy web clients.
Implemented horizontal pod autoscaling in Kubernetes based on CPU utilization above 70% and custom metrics for queue depth.
Using Elasticsearch for full-text search instead of PostgreSQL full-text because we need faceted search, fuzzy matching, and better relevance scoring.
Decided on eventual consistency for analytics data pipeline. Chose Apache Airflow for orchestration with daily batch jobs at 2 AM UTC when traffic is lowest.
Implemented API rate limiting with token bucket algorithm at 1000 requests per hour per API key to prevent abuse.
Chose S3 for storing user-uploaded images with CloudFront CDN for distribution. Implemented image resizing at upload time to reduce bandwidth costs.
Using database read replicas for reporting queries to avoid impacting production write performance. Replica lag acceptable up to 5 minutes for our use case.
Adopted Temporal for workflow orchestration to handle long-running processes with retry logic and visibility into execution state.
Implemented server-side rendering with Next.js for SEO-critical pages while keeping SPA architecture for authenticated user dashboard.
Chose Consul for service discovery over hardcoded DNS because services need to dynamically register and health checks run continuously.
Using materialized views in PostgreSQL for expensive analytics queries instead of moving to separate data warehouse. Refreshed hourly via cron job.
Implemented optimistic locking with version fields to handle concurrent updates in distributed environment without pessimistic locks.
Switched to connection pooling with PgBouncer because application was exhausting database connections. Pool size set to 20 per app instance.
Chose WebSockets over HTTP polling for real-time notifications to reduce server load and improve latency. Fallback to SSE for older browsers.
Implemented database sharding by user_id hash for users table. Each shard handles roughly 10M users with consistent hashing for future rebalancing.
Using Terraform for infrastructure as code instead of manual AWS console changes. All production changes require reviewed and approved PRs.
Adopted CQRS pattern for order management system with separate read and write models to optimize for different access patterns.
Implemented canary deployments rolling out to 5% of traffic first, monitoring error rates for 30 minutes before full rollout.
Chose Memcached over Redis for simple session caching because we don't need persistence or complex data structures.
Using Lambda functions for image processing pipeline triggered by S3 events. More cost-effective than keeping EC2 instances running 24/7.
Implemented distributed tracing with OpenTelemetry across microservices to debug latency issues. Jaeger for trace visualization.
Chose multi-region active-active deployment for 99.99% availability SLA. Route53 health checks with automatic failover between regions.
Using database migration tool Flyway with versioned SQL scripts checked into git. Migrations run automatically during deployment.
Implemented saga pattern for distributed transactions across order, inventory, and payment services with compensating transactions for rollback.
Chose Snowflake IDs over UUID for primary keys to maintain time-based ordering while avoiding coordination overhead of auto-increment.
Using Nginx as reverse proxy with request buffering disabled for streaming uploads to reduce memory usage.
Implemented write-through caching strategy for user preferences. Updates go to database first, then cache to maintain consistency.
Chose ClickHouse for analytics over PostgreSQL because query performance on billion-row tables is 100x faster for our aggregation workload.
Using feature flags with LaunchDarkly to decouple deployment from release and enable A/B testing in production.
Implemented CDC with Debezium to capture database changes and publish to Kafka for real-time data synchronization across systems.
Chose Prometheus for metrics collection with Grafana dashboards. Alertmanager sends PagerDuty alerts when error rate exceeds 1% over 5 minutes.
Using object storage versioning in S3 for backup and compliance. Lifecycle policy moves versions to Glacier after 90 days.
Implemented API gateway with Kong for centralized authentication, rate limiting, and request logging across all microservices.
Chose cassandra for time-series sensor data due to linear write scalability and built-in time-based partitioning. Retain data for 30 days.
Using JWT tokens for stateless authentication with 15-minute expiry and refresh token rotation to balance security and user experience.
Implemented database connection retry logic with exponential backoff starting at 100ms, max 5 attempts to handle transient failures.
Chose ECS Fargate over EKS to reduce operational overhead. Team size doesn't justify Kubernetes complexity for our workload.
Using pub/sub pattern with RabbitMQ for order events. Dead letter queue configured to capture failed messages after 3 retry attempts.
Implemented compression with gzip for API responses over 1KB. Reduced bandwidth costs by 60% with minimal CPU overhead.
Chose Aurora PostgreSQL over RDS for automatic failover and read replica scaling. Enables up to 15 read replicas vs 5 in standard RDS.
Using DNS-based service discovery with Route53 private hosted zones instead of Consul to reduce infrastructure complexity.
Implemented asynchronous job processing with Sidekiq for email sending and report generation. 5 worker processes handling up to 50 concurrent jobs.
Chose PostgreSQL over MongoDB for user data because we need ACID transactions for financial records and complex joins across normalized tables.
Implemented Redis for session storage instead of in-memory to enable horizontal scaling of API servers without sticky sessions.
Adopted GraphQL federation to let teams independently deploy their domain APIs while maintaining a unified gateway for clients.
Switched from REST to gRPC for internal service communication—cut latency by 40% and got type safety with protobuf definitions.
Using Kubernetes StatefulSets for Kafka brokers to maintain stable network identities and persistent storage across pod restarts.
Implemented CQRS pattern for order management: writes go to PostgreSQL for consistency, reads served from Elasticsearch for complex filtering and search performance.
Selected Cloudflare Workers for edge compute to render personalized content closer to users, reducing TTFB from 800ms to 120ms.
Chose event sourcing for audit trail requirements—storing every state change as immutable events in Kafka lets us reconstruct history and satisfy compliance.
Using Cassandra for time-series metrics storage due to write-heavy workload and linear scalability—handling 500K writes/sec across 12 nodes.
Implemented circuit breakers with Hystrix for third-party payment gateway calls to fail fast and prevent cascade failures during their outages.
Adopted blue-green deployment strategy to achieve zero-downtime releases and instant rollback capability for the main API.
Using Amazon SQS with dead letter queues for async job processing—prioritizing operational simplicity over custom Kafka setup for our current scale.
Chose Terraform over CloudFormation for infrastructure-as-code to maintain multi-cloud optionality and use a single toolchain across AWS and GCP.
Implementing API gateway rate limiting with token bucket algorithm: 100 req/min per user, 10K/min per API key to prevent abuse.
Selected DynamoDB for shopping cart storage—single-digit millisecond latency, auto-scaling, and TTL for automatic cart expiration after 7 days.
Using CDC with Debezium to stream PostgreSQL changes to data warehouse—avoids batch ETL jobs and enables near real-time analytics.
Adopted saga pattern for distributed transactions in microservices—using choreography with events rather than orchestration to reduce coupling.
Chose Varnish for HTTP caching layer in front of application servers, configured with grace mode to serve stale content during backend failures.
Implemented JWT with short-lived access tokens (15 min) and refresh tokens (7 days) stored in httpOnly cookies to balance security and UX.
Using RabbitMQ with priority queues for task processing—premium customer requests get higher priority than batch operations.
Selected Envoy as service mesh sidecar for observability, traffic management, and mTLS between services without changing application code.
Chose ElastiCache Redis Cluster mode for multi-AZ availability and automatic failover—worth the complexity for our 99.99% uptime SLA.
Implementing database-per-service pattern but with shared schemas for reference data—balances autonomy with data consistency for lookup tables.
Using CDN edge caching with surrogate keys for instant purge across thousands of related assets when content updates.
Adopted WebSockets over Server-Sent Events for bidirectional real-time features—needed client-to-server push for collaborative editing.
Chose TimescaleDB over vanilla PostgreSQL for IoT sensor data—hypertable partitioning and compression reduced storage by 70%.
Implementing materialized views in PostgreSQL refreshed every 5 minutes for dashboard queries—acceptable staleness for 100x faster reads.
Selected containerd over Docker as runtime in Kubernetes for reduced overhead and better alignment with CNCF ecosystem.
Using AWS Lambda for image resizing triggered by S3 uploads—pays for itself versus maintaining always-on workers for sporadic workload.
Chose Linkerd over Istio for service mesh—simpler architecture and lower resource overhead for our current needs.
Implemented write-through cache for product catalog: updates write to DB and cache atomically to avoid stale reads.
Using Prometheus for metrics with Thanos for long-term storage—federation lets each team run their own Prometheus while maintaining global view.
Selected Aurora PostgreSQL over RDS for automatic storage scaling and faster failover, despite higher cost.
Adopted OpenAPI spec-first approach: define APIs in YAML, generate server stubs and client SDKs to maintain contract consistency.
Using Kafka Streams for real-time analytics instead of Spark—simpler deployment as library within existing services and lower latency.
Chose async Python with FastAPI over Flask for new services—native async/await support handles I/O-bound workloads more efficiently.
Implementing database read replicas with application-level routing: writes to primary, analytics queries to replica to isolate workloads.
Selected ClickHouse for analytics database—columnar storage and aggressive compression handle billions of events with sub-second query times.
Using feature flags with LaunchDarkly for gradual rollouts—can enable features for 5% of users and instantly disable if metrics degrade.
Chose monorepo with Nx for frontend—shared component library and coordinated deployments outweigh increased CI/CD complexity.
Implementing canary deployments with automatic rollback based on error rate thresholds monitored in real-time.
Using S3 Transfer Acceleration for user file uploads—worth the cost for international users with 50-500% speed improvement.
Selected Apache Pulsar over Kafka for message queue—native multi-tenancy and tiered storage fit our data retention requirements.
Chose HashiCorp Vault for secrets management with dynamic database credentials rotated every 24 hours.
Implementing connection pooling with PgBouncer to reduce PostgreSQL connection overhead from thousands of Lambda invocations.
Using GitHub Actions over Jenkins—easier to maintain as code and free for our private repo count.
Selected Tailscale for internal service authentication—WireGuard-based mesh VPN simpler than managing VPN servers or complex IAM rules.
Chose SQLite for edge devices syncing to cloud—embedded database eliminates deployment complexity for offline-first mobile app.
Implementing cache warming during deployment—pre-populate Redis before shifting traffic to avoid cold start performance degradation.
Using ArgoCD for GitOps deployment workflow—git commits automatically sync to Kubernetes clusters with full audit trail.
Chose PostgreSQL over MongoDB for user account data because we need ACID transactions for financial records and the schema is well-defined and relational.
Switched from REST to GraphQL for the mobile API to reduce over-fetching and give clients more flexible queries.
Implemented Redis caching layer in front of the product catalog service. Cache hit rate improved to 87% and reduced database load by 60%. Using a 15-minute TTL with cache-aside pattern.
Adopted Kubernetes over ECS because our team already has K8s expertise and we need multi-cloud portability for the future.
Using RabbitMQ for order processing queue instead of SQS to avoid vendor lock-in and get better message routing features.
Split monolith into microservices starting with the notification service since it has clear boundaries and independent scaling needs.
Went with OAuth 2.0 + JWT for authentication instead of session cookies to support our mobile apps and third-party integrations.
Deployed Elasticsearch for search functionality because our PostgreSQL full-text search was too slow for autocomplete and faceted filtering on 10M+ products.
Using blue-green deployment strategy to eliminate downtime during releases.
Chose gRPC for internal service communication due to better performance than REST and built-in code generation from protobuf definitions.
Implemented circuit breaker pattern with Hystrix for calls to the payment gateway. Prevents cascade failures and provides graceful degradation when the gateway is slow or down.
Switched to S3 for storing user uploads instead of local filesystem to support horizontal scaling of web servers.
Using Cassandra for time-series analytics data because we need to handle 500k writes/second and linear scalability is more important than strong consistency.
Adopted API Gateway pattern with Kong to handle rate limiting, authentication, and request routing centrally instead of duplicating logic in each service.
Implemented database read replicas with read/write splitting to handle increased query load without upgrading the primary database instance.
Chose DynamoDB for session storage due to single-digit millisecond latency requirements and ability to auto-scale based on traffic.
Using Kafka instead of RabbitMQ for event streaming between services because we need to replay events for analytics and maintain event ordering at high throughput.
Went with serverless Lambda functions for image processing to avoid maintaining infrastructure and only pay for actual processing time.
Implemented CDN caching with CloudFront for static assets and API responses to reduce latency for global users.
Chose TypeScript over JavaScript for backend services to catch type errors at compile time and improve code maintainability.
Using database sharding based on user_id hash to distribute data across 8 PostgreSQL instances and handle growth beyond 1TB.
Adopted event sourcing for the ordering system to maintain complete audit trail and enable temporal queries.
Switched to async/await pattern instead of callbacks for all Node.js services to improve code readability and error handling.
Using Terraform for infrastructure as code to version control our AWS resources and enable reproducible environments.
Implemented API versioning in URL path (/v1/, /v2/) instead of headers for better visibility and easier testing.
Chose Prometheus and Grafana for monitoring over Datadog to keep costs down and maintain control over metrics data.
Using materialized views in PostgreSQL for complex analytics queries that were timing out. Refresh every 5 minutes via cron job.
Adopted saga pattern for distributed transactions across order, inventory, and payment services since we can't use 2PC across microservices.
Switched from polling to webhooks for third-party integrations to reduce unnecessary API calls and improve real-time responsiveness.
Using connection pooling with PgBouncer to handle 10k concurrent connections without exhausting database connection limits.
Chose multi-region deployment with active-active setup for 99.99% uptime SLA requirements.
Implemented write-through caching for user preferences to ensure cache consistency and prevent stale reads.
Using Neo4j graph database for social network features because relationship queries are 100x faster than joins in PostgreSQL for our use case.
Adopted contract testing with Pact between microservices to catch breaking changes before deployment.
Switched to Docker multi-stage builds to reduce image size from 1.2GB to 180MB and speed up deployments.
Using lazy loading for service initialization to reduce container startup time from 45s to 8s.
Chose CQRS pattern to separate read and write models for the reporting system, allowing different optimization strategies for each.
Implemented rate limiting with token bucket algorithm at 100 requests per minute per API key to prevent abuse.
Using MySQL for legacy compatibility but all new services use PostgreSQL for better JSON support and concurrent write performance.
Adopted feature flags with LaunchDarkly to enable trunk-based development and gradual rollouts.
Switched to WebSockets for real-time notifications instead of HTTP polling to reduce server load and improve latency.
Using Memcached for ephemeral session data and Redis for persistent cache because Memcached uses less memory for simple key-value pairs.
Chose schema-per-tenant database isolation for multi-tenancy to ensure data separation and enable per-customer backup/restore.
Implemented idempotency keys for payment API to safely handle duplicate requests from network retries.
Using canary deployments with 5% traffic routing to detect issues before full rollout.
Switched from monolithic Docker image to separate images per service to speed up CI/CD and reduce deployment coupling.
Chose etcd for distributed configuration management because it integrates well with Kubernetes and provides strong consistency.
Implemented database connection retry logic with exponential backoff to handle transient network failures gracefully.
Using BFF (Backend for Frontend) pattern with separate API layers for web and mobile to optimize payload sizes and reduce round trips.
Adopted OpenAPI specification for API documentation to auto-generate client SDKs and enable contract-first development.

Middleware pattern: all Express middleware functions in this codebase follow the pattern of accepting (req, res, next) and must call next() for success or next(error) for errors. Never send responses directly from middleware - let route handlers do that. Exception: error-handling middleware which has signature (err, req, res, next).

Auth flow: JWT tokens stored in httpOnly cookies, not localStorage. Access token expires in 15min, refresh token in 7 days. Refresh endpoint at POST /api/auth/refresh checks refresh token from cookie, issues new access token. Client-side axios interceptor catches 401s and attempts refresh once before redirecting to login.

Error handling convention in Python services: all custom exceptions inherit from AppError base class. AppError has status_code, message, and details fields. FastAPI exception handler catches AppError and returns {"error": {"code": ..., "message": ..., "details": ...}} format. Use specific subclasses like ValidationError(400), NotFoundError(404), UnauthorizedError(401).

Testing pattern: all TypeScript unit tests use describe/it blocks from Jest. Each test file mirrors source structure (src/services/user.ts -> tests/services/user.test.ts). Mock external dependencies using jest.mock() at top of file. Use beforeEach for test setup, afterEach for cleanup. Test names follow pattern 'should <expected behavior> when <condition>'.

Naming standard for React components: PascalCase for component files and exports. Custom hooks prefixed with 'use' (useAuth, usePagination). Event handlers prefixed with 'handle' (handleClick, handleSubmit). Boolean props/state prefixed with 'is', 'has', or 'should' (isLoading, hasError, shouldValidate).

Module structure in Rust: each module has mod.rs that re-exports public API. Private implementation details in separate files. Pattern: src/database/mod.rs exports connect(), query() functions while connection.rs and query_builder.rs are private. Keeps clean public interface.

Type pattern in TypeScript: use type for unions and primitives, interface for object shapes. Prefix interfaces with 'I' only for abstract implementations. Suffix 'Props' for React component props (UserCardProps), 'Config' for configuration objects (DatabaseConfig), 'Response' for API responses (UserResponse). Use 'Partial<T>' for update payloads.

Async pattern in Go: always pass context.Context as first parameter to functions that do I/O. Check ctx.Err() before long operations. Pattern: func GetUser(ctx context.Context, id string) (*User, error). Use context.WithTimeout in handlers, propagate context through entire request chain. Cancel context on HTTP request cancellation.

Repository pattern: all database access goes through repository interfaces. Example: UserRepository interface defines Create, FindByID, Update, Delete methods. PostgresUserRepository implements the interface. Services depend on interface, not concrete implementation. Makes testing with mock repositories trivial.

Error handling in Rust: use Result<T, E> for fallible operations, never panic in library code. Pattern: return Err(DatabaseError::ConnectionFailed) instead of panicking. Use ? operator for propagation. Define custom error enums with thiserror crate. Wrap external errors: map_err(|e| DatabaseError::QueryFailed(e.to_string())).

Middleware ordering in Express: helmet() first for security headers, then cors(), then body parsers (express.json()), then request logging, then auth middleware (requireAuth, optionalAuth), then route handlers, finally error handler. Order matters - error handler must be last.

Environment config pattern: use dotenv for local dev, require all env vars to be declared in config/schema.ts with Zod validation. App crashes on startup if required vars missing or invalid type. Pattern: const config = ConfigSchema.parse(process.env). No scattered process.env.X access throughout codebase.

GraphQL resolver pattern: resolvers live in src/graphql/resolvers/{Query,Mutation,Type}. Each resolver gets (parent, args, context, info) params. Context contains user, dataloaders, and services. Never instantiate services in resolvers - inject via context. Use DataLoader for N+1 query prevention.

Python async pattern: all I/O-bound functions are async/await. Database calls, HTTP requests, file I/O use await. Pattern: async def get_user(user_id: str) -> User. Use asyncio.gather() for concurrent operations. Never use blocking calls like requests.get() in async functions - use httpx instead.

Factory pattern for test data: create factories using factory_boy (Python) or fishery (TypeScript). Pattern: UserFactory.create({email: 'test@example.com'}) generates valid user with defaults. Use sequences for unique values. Factories in tests/factories/ directory. Never hardcode test data in test files.

API versioning: all routes prefixed with /api/v1/, /api/v2/. Breaking changes require new version. Keep old versions for 6 months after new version release. Version extracted in middleware, stored in req.apiVersion. Route handlers can branch on version if needed. Deprecation warnings in response headers.

Dependency injection in Go: use constructor functions that return interfaces. Pattern: func NewUserService(repo UserRepository, logger Logger) UserService. Main function wires dependencies. Never use global variables or init() for services. Makes testing easy - pass mocks to constructors.

React state management: use React Query (TanStack Query) for server state, Zustand for client UI state. Never store server data in Zustand. Pattern: useQuery(['user', userId], () => fetchUser(userId)) for fetching. Zustand stores only UI concerns like sidebar open/closed, selected tab, modal state.

Logging convention: structured logging with Winston (Node) or structlog (Python). Every log includes requestId, userId (if authenticated), timestamp. Pattern: logger.info('user.created', {userId, email, requestId}). Use log levels consistently: debug (verbose), info (normal operations), warn (recoverable errors), error (needs attention). Never log sensitive data like passwords or tokens.

Database migration pattern: use Alembic (Python/SQLAlchemy) or Flyway (Java). Migrations numbered sequentially (001_initial_schema.sql, 002_add_users_table.sql). Never modify existing migrations - create new ones. Include both up and down migrations. Run migrations automatically on deployment in staging, require manual approval for production.

Type guard pattern in TypeScript: create type predicates for runtime type checking. Pattern: function isUser(obj: unknown): obj is User { return typeof obj === 'object' && obj !== null && 'id' in obj && 'email' in obj; }. Use for API responses and user input validation. Narrows TypeScript types properly.

Middleware for request validation: use Zod schemas in Express middleware. Pattern: validate(UserCreateSchema) middleware parses req.body and attaches validated data to req.validated. Route handler accesses req.validated.body with full type safety. Validation middleware sends 400 with detailed errors on validation failure.

Service layer pattern: controllers are thin, just handle HTTP concerns (parsing request, sending response). All business logic in service layer. Pattern: UserController calls userService.createUser(data). Services orchestrate repositories, external APIs, events. Services return domain models or throw domain exceptions, controllers translate to HTTP responses.

Event-driven architecture: services emit domain events to event bus (EventEmitter or message queue). Pattern: after creating user, emit('user.created', {userId, email}). Event listeners in separate files (src/events/listeners/). Listeners handle side effects (send welcome email, create audit log). Keeps business logic decoupled.

Monorepo package naming: scoped packages under @company namespace. Pattern: @acme/ui-components, @acme/api-client, @acme/shared-types. Shared types in separate package imported by both frontend and backend. Use Turborepo or Nx for build orchestration. Package dependencies declared explicitly in package.json.

Error boundary pattern in React: wrap route components with ErrorBoundary that catches render errors. Pattern: <ErrorBoundary fallback={<ErrorPage />}><UserDashboard /></ErrorBoundary>. Log errors to monitoring service (Sentry). Show user-friendly error UI. Reset boundary state on navigation.

Transaction pattern in Python SQLAlchemy: use context manager for database transactions. Pattern: with Session() as session, session.begin(): user = User(...); session.add(user); session.commit(). Automatically rolls back on exception. Never manually call rollback unless custom recovery logic needed.

Rate limiting middleware: use express-rate-limit with Redis store. Different limits per endpoint type: 100/15min for reads, 20/15min for writes, 5/15min for auth. Key by IP for anonymous, by userId for authenticated. Pattern: authRateLimit middleware applied to POST /api/auth/login. Return 429 with Retry-After header.

API response format: all endpoints return consistent envelope. Success: {"data": {...}, "meta": {page, total}}. Error: {"error": {"code": "ERR_NOT_FOUND", "message": "User not found", "details": {...}}}. Lists always include pagination metadata. Timestamps in ISO 8601 format. Null fields included, never omitted.

Builder pattern for complex objects in Rust: use typed builder pattern. Pattern: User::builder().email("test@example.com").name("Test").build()? Returns Result, validates required fields at compile time with typestate pattern. Each builder method consumes self and returns next state. Can't build without required fields.

Testing database setup: use testcontainers (Java/Python) or docker-compose for integration tests. Each test class gets fresh database instance. Pattern: @BeforeAll starts container, @BeforeEach runs migrations, @AfterEach clears data, @AfterAll stops container. Tests run in parallel with isolated databases. No shared test database.

Feature flag pattern: use feature flag service (LaunchDarkly or custom). Check flags in service layer, not controllers or components. Pattern: if (featureFlags.isEnabled('new-checkout-flow', userId)) { ... }. Flags evaluated per-user for gradual rollouts. Clean up flags within 2 sprints of 100% rollout.

Workspace organization in Rust Cargo: use workspace in root Cargo.toml. Pattern: crates/api, crates/domain, crates/infrastructure. Domain crate has no external dependencies. API depends on domain and infrastructure. Shared dependencies managed in workspace Cargo.toml. Each crate has focused responsibility.

Hook composition pattern in React: compose multiple hooks into custom hooks. Pattern: useUserProfile() calls useQuery, useMemo, and useCallback internally. Export only the composed hook. Encapsulates related logic. Test custom hooks with @testing-library/react-hooks. Keep hooks pure and side-effect-free except data fetching.

Background job pattern: use Celery (Python) or Bull (Node) for async jobs. Pattern: send_welcome_email.delay(user_id) queues job. Job functions accept serializable arguments only (IDs, not objects). Jobs are idempotent - can run multiple times safely. Include retry logic with exponential backoff. Set max retries and dead letter queue.

CSS module naming: use BEM (Block Element Modifier) within CSS modules. Pattern: .userCard, .userCard__title, .userCard__title--highlighted. File: UserCard.module.css imported as styles. Usage: className={styles.userCard}. Scoped by default, no global pollution. Compose with clsx for conditional classes.

Go interface segregation: small interfaces, single method when possible. Pattern: type Validator interface { Validate() error }, type Repository interface { Save(ctx context.Context, entity Entity) error }. Compose interfaces when needed. Easier to mock, easier to implement, follows ISP. Avoid kitchen-sink interfaces.

Saga pattern for distributed transactions: use orchestration with state machine. Pattern: OrderSaga coordinates: reserve inventory, charge payment, send confirmation. Each step has compensating action for rollback. Saga state persisted. If step fails, execute compensation for completed steps. Use temporal.io or custom implementation.

API client generation: use OpenAPI spec to generate TypeScript client with openapi-generator. Pattern: npm run generate-client creates src/generated/api with typed client. Import ApiClient, call methods with full autocomplete. Keep spec as source of truth. Regenerate client on API changes. Commit generated code for review.

Decorator pattern in Python: use functools.wraps for proper decorator implementation. Pattern: @require_auth, @measure_time, @retry(max_attempts=3). Decorators preserve function metadata. Stack decorators for composition. Create decorator factory for parameters: @cache(ttl=300). Use for cross-cutting concerns.

CQRS pattern: separate command and query models. Pattern: UserCommandService handles creates/updates, UserQueryService handles reads. Different databases/schemas allowed. Commands return success/failure, queries return data. Commands emit events picked up by query model updaters. Eventual consistency acceptable for reads.

Form handling in React: use react-hook-form with Zod resolver. Pattern: const {register, handleSubmit, formState: {errors}} = useForm({resolver: zodResolver(UserSchema)}). Register inputs, Zod validates on submit. Display errors from errors object. Server validation errors merged with setError(). Handles dirty state, touched fields automatically.

Option/Result pattern in Rust: never return null, use Option<T> for optional values. Pattern: fn find_user(id: &str) -> Option<User>. Chain with map, and_then, unwrap_or. For errors use Result<T, E>. Pattern: fn create_user(data: UserData) -> Result<User, Error>. Explicit error handling, no exceptions.

Database connection pooling: configure connection pool at startup. Pattern: Pool max 20 connections, min 5, idle timeout 10min, connection timeout 5sec. One pool per database. Pass pool to repositories via constructor injection. Never create connections per request. Monitor pool metrics (active, idle, wait time).

Websocket message handling: use discriminated unions for message types. Pattern: type Message = {type: 'chat', payload: ChatPayload} | {type: 'notification', payload: NotifPayload}. Switch on message.type. Each handler function typed by payload. Use Zod to validate incoming messages. Maintain connection registry for user presence.

Code organization by feature: group by feature, not by type. Pattern: src/features/user/{api, components, hooks, types, utils}. Keep feature-specific code together. Shared code in src/shared/. Feature folders are self-contained modules. Easier to find related code, easier to delete features. Scales better than src/{components, hooks, utils}.

Pagination pattern: cursor-based pagination for infinite scroll, offset-based for page numbers. Pattern: GET /api/users?cursor=abc123&limit=20 returns {data: [...], nextCursor: 'def456', hasMore: true}. Cursor encodes position (base64 of ID+timestamp). More efficient than offset for large datasets. No page skipping.

Mock service worker for testing: use MSW to mock API calls in tests and development. Pattern: handlers defined in src/mocks/handlers.ts, setupServer() in test setup, setupWorker() for browser dev. Same handlers for tests and local dev. Mock responses match real API. Enables frontend development without backend running.

Observer pattern for state updates: use pub/sub for component communication. Pattern: eventBus.emit('cart.updated', {itemCount}), eventBus.on('cart.updated', handler). Components subscribe in useEffect, unsubscribe on cleanup. Alternative to prop drilling. Keep events domain-focused, not component-specific. Document events in central registry.

Type-safe environment variables in Go: use struct with tags and validation. Pattern: type Config struct { Port int `env:"PORT,required" envDefault:"8080"`; DBUrl string `env:"DATABASE_URL,required"` }. Parse with env library. Panic on startup if invalid. Single source of truth for config. Access config.Port instead of os.Getenv scattered everywhere.

Middleware functions in our Express apps always follow the pattern: async (req, res, next) => { try { /* logic */ next(); } catch (err) { next(err); } }. Never throw directly, always pass to next(). Error middleware is registered last and has signature (err, req, res, next).

TypeScript error handling: custom errors extend Error base class with a readonly 'code' property. Format is like AppError, ValidationError, NotFoundError. All thrown errors must be serializable for logging. Add toJSON() method that includes timestamp, code, message, and optional context.

Auth flow uses JWT refresh tokens stored in httpOnly cookies, access tokens in memory on client. Middleware checks Authorization: Bearer <token> header first, falls back to cookie if missing. Refresh endpoint is POST /api/auth/refresh and returns new access token.

Python test fixtures in conftest.py follow naming: db_session, mock_user_service, test_client. Async tests use @pytest.mark.asyncio. Database tests get @pytest.mark.db decorator. Factory fixtures use factory pattern: user_factory returns a callable that creates users with overridable defaults.

TypeScript naming: interfaces start with I (IUserRepository), types are descriptive nouns (UserDTO, CreateUserRequest). Enums are PascalCase singular (UserRole, not UserRoles). Boolean variables/functions start with is/has/should. Private class members prefixed with underscore.

Go error handling: always check errors immediately with if err != nil. Wrap errors with fmt.Errorf using %w verb for error chains. Custom errors implement error interface. Never panic in library code, only in main or unrecoverable situations. Use errors.Is() and errors.As() for checking error types.

Module structure in Node projects: index.ts exports public API only, implementation in separate files. Each module has types.ts, errors.ts, utils.ts if needed. Barrel exports pattern but careful with circular deps. Tests live in __tests__ folder at same level as source.

Rust Result type everywhere: fn process() -> Result<T, AppError>. Use ? operator for propagation. Match on Results only at boundaries (handlers, main). Convert external errors with map_err(). Custom error enum derives Debug, Display, and implements std::error::Error.

Async patterns in TypeScript: prefer async/await over raw promises. Use Promise.all() for concurrent operations, not sequential awaits. Timeout pattern: Promise.race([operation(), timeout(5000)]). Long-running tasks return AbortController for cancellation.

Repository pattern: interface defines data methods (find, create, update, delete), implementations handle DB specifics. Never expose ORM entities directly, map to domain models at repository boundary. Repository functions return domain types, accept DTOs or domain types.

Python type hints required for all public functions: def get_user(user_id: int) -> Optional[User]. Use TypedDict for complex dicts, dataclasses for models. Generic types for containers: List[User], Dict[str, Any]. Use Protocol for structural typing. mypy strict mode enabled.

Go context pattern: first parameter always ctx context.Context. Pass through entire call chain. Use context.WithTimeout() at entry points (HTTP handlers). Check ctx.Done() in loops. Store request-scoped data with context.WithValue() but sparingly, prefer explicit params.

Testing conventions: unit tests mock all external deps, integration tests use real DB/services but isolated, e2e tests use full stack. Test file naming: feature.test.ts or test_feature.py. Test names: describe('User Service', () => { it('should create user when valid data provided', ...).

TypeScript dependency injection: constructor injection only, no property injection. Interfaces for dependencies. DI container configured at startup. Services registered as singletons or transient. Use @Injectable() decorator pattern. Container.resolve() called only at composition root.

Middleware chaining pattern: auth middleware runs first, validates token, attaches user to req.user. Then permission middleware checks req.user.role. Then validation middleware. Then route handler. Each middleware single responsibility. Compose with app.use() or router-level.

Python async patterns: use asyncio.gather() for concurrent tasks. Session management with async context managers: async with session() as s. Connection pools initialized at startup, closed at shutdown. Use asyncio.create_task() for fire-and-forget. Semaphores for rate limiting: async with sem.

Error response format standardized: { error: { code: 'VALIDATION_ERROR', message: 'Invalid input', details: [...], timestamp: '...', requestId: '...' } }. HTTP status codes: 400 validation, 401 auth, 403 forbidden, 404 not found, 500 server error. Never expose stack traces in production.

Rust ownership patterns: accept &str not String for read-only, &[T] not Vec<T>. Return owned types. Use Cow<str> when might need owned or borrowed. Clone only when necessary, prefer references. Use Arc<T> for shared ownership, Rc<T> for single-threaded. Mutex<T> for interior mutability.

Database migrations: sequential numbered files 001_initial_schema.sql, 002_add_users_table.sql. Never modify old migrations, always create new one. Down migrations required. Run migrations at app startup in dev, manually in prod. Track with schema_migrations table.

Factory pattern for tests: createUser({email: 'override@test.com'}) merges with defaults. Factories return plain objects, not ORM instances. Async factories for DB persistence: await createUserInDb(). Traits for variations: createUser.admin(), createUser.inactive(). Sequences for unique values.

Go interface conventions: small focused interfaces, often single method. Name with -er suffix: Reader, Writer, Handler. Accept interfaces, return structs. Define interfaces at usage site, not implementation. Use io.Reader, io.Writer where applicable. Empty interface for truly generic: interface{}.

TypeScript generics: avoid any, use unknown and type guards. Generic constraints with extends: <T extends BaseModel>. Mapped types for transformations: type Optional<T> = { [K in keyof T]?: T[K] }. Conditional types: type IsString<T> = T extends string ? true : false. Utility types: Partial, Pick, Omit.

Logging conventions: structured logging with JSON. Levels: debug, info, warn, error. Context fields: requestId, userId, method, path. logger.info('User created', { userId, email }) not string interpolation. Sensitive data (passwords, tokens) never logged. Correlation IDs propagated through async calls.

Python decorator patterns: @require_auth, @validate_input, @cache_result. Decorators for cross-cutting concerns. Use functools.wraps() to preserve metadata. Parameterized decorators: @retry(times=3, delay=1). Stack decorators carefully, order matters. Async decorators for async functions.

API versioning: /api/v1/users, /api/v2/users. Version in URL path, not header. Major version only. Maintain old versions minimum 6 months after deprecation notice. Version constant in config. Router maps versions to handlers. Shared code in common module.

Rust trait patterns: implement From/Into for conversions. Implement Display for user-facing strings, Debug for dev. Use derive macros: #[derive(Debug, Clone, PartialEq, Serialize, Deserialize)]. Implement Default when sensible. Use AsRef/AsMut for generic borrowing.

Config management: separate files per environment (config.dev.ts, config.prod.ts). Environment variables override file config. Required vars validated at startup, fail fast if missing. Use dotenv only in development. Sensitive values from secrets manager, not env vars in prod. Type-safe config objects.

Go struct tags: json tags for serialization: `json:"user_id,omitempty"`. validate tags for validation: `validate:"required,email"`. db tags for ORM: `db:"user_id"`. Multiple tags space-separated. Use omitempty for optional fields. Snake_case for JSON keys matching DB columns.

Builder pattern for complex objects: User.builder().withName(name).withEmail(email).build(). Validates in build() method. Required fields in constructor, optional via methods. Immutable result. Fluent interface returns self. Useful for tests and configurations.

TypeScript module augmentation for extending third-party types: declare module 'express-serve-static-core' { interface Request { user?: User; requestId: string; } }. Keeps types in sync with middleware. Place in types/index.d.ts.

Python context managers: use for resource management. with open_db_session() as session: pattern. Implement __enter__ and __exit__. Use contextlib.contextmanager decorator for generator style. Async context managers with async with and __aenter__/__aexit__. Always cleanup in __exit__.

Pagination pattern: limit/offset initially, cursor-based for large datasets. Response format: { data: [...], meta: { total, page, limit, hasMore } }. Max limit enforced server-side. Cursor is opaque token (base64 encoded position). Include cursor in meta: nextCursor, prevCursor.

Go table-driven tests: func TestUserValidation(t *testing.T) { tests := []struct { name string; input User; wantErr bool }{{...}} for _, tt := range tests { t.Run(tt.name, func(t *testing.T) {...}) }}. One test function, multiple cases. Subtests for parallel execution.

Singleton pattern for services: lazy initialization with double-check locking in Go. In TypeScript, module scope const instance. In Python, use module-level instance. In Rust, use lazy_static! or once_cell. Prefer dependency injection over global singletons. Singletons for DB pools, caches, config.

TypeScript discriminated unions: type Result = { success: true; data: T } | { success: false; error: Error }. Discriminant field enables type narrowing. Use with switch or if. Pattern for API responses, state machines. Tag field like 'type' or 'kind' as discriminator.

Background job pattern: jobs enqueued to Redis/RabbitMQ. Worker processes poll queue. Job handler structure: async function handleJobType(payload: JobPayload): Promise<void>. Retry logic with exponential backoff. Dead letter queue for failed jobs. Job status tracking in DB.

Rust error handling with thiserror crate: #[derive(Error, Debug)] enum AppError { #[error("User not found: {0}")] NotFound(String), }. Automatic Display impl. Use with anyhow for applications, thiserror for libraries. Convert with ? operator.

File upload pattern: presigned URLs for direct-to-S3 upload. Client requests POST /api/uploads/presign, gets URL. Client uploads to S3. Client POSTs metadata to backend. Validate file type, size limits. Virus scan async. Store file key, not full URL. Generate signed URLs for retrieval.

Python ABC for interfaces: from abc import ABC, abstractmethod. class UserRepository(ABC): @abstractmethod def find_by_id(self, id: int) -> Optional[User]. Forces implementation. Use for defining contracts. Combine with Protocol for structural typing vs nominal.

Rate limiting middleware: keyed by IP or user ID. Redis for distributed counting. Sliding window algorithm. Headers: X-RateLimit-Limit, X-RateLimit-Remaining, X-RateLimit-Reset. 429 status when exceeded. Different limits per endpoint: /api/auth/login stricter than GET endpoints.

Go functional options: func WithTimeout(d time.Duration) Option { return func(c *Client) { c.timeout = d }}. Constructor accepts ...Option. Exported With* functions for configuration. Flexible, backward compatible. Self-documenting. Pattern: NewClient(url, WithTimeout(5*time.Second)).

Observer pattern for events: EventEmitter in Node. event.on('user.created', handler). Handlers async, awaited with Promise.all(). Event names namespaced: entity.action. Payload includes timestamp, actor, entity. Used for notifications, analytics, cache invalidation. Decouple modules.

TypeScript readonly everywhere: readonly properties in interfaces, ReadonlyArray<T>, readonly tuples. Immutable data flow. Use Readonly<T> utility type. Prevents accidental mutations. Deep readonly with DeepReadonly<T> custom type. Enforced by compiler, documents intent.

Validation middleware: use Joi/Zod/yup for schema validation. Validate req.body, req.query, req.params separately. Validation error returns 400 with field-specific errors: { errors: [{ field: 'email', message: 'Invalid email' }] }. Schemas colocated with routes or in validators/ folder.

Rust async patterns: async fn with .await. Use tokio::spawn for concurrent tasks. tokio::select! for racing futures. Channels for communication: mpsc, oneshot. Arc<Mutex<T>> for shared mutable state. Use async_trait for trait with async methods. Pin for self-referential futures.

Transaction pattern: in service layer, begin transaction, pass to repositories. On success commit, on error rollback. Use DB transaction context: await db.transaction(async (tx) => { await userRepo.create(user, tx); await auditRepo.log(action, tx); }). Automatically rolls back on exception.

Python dataclasses: @dataclass decorator for models. Automatic __init__, __repr__, __eq__. Use field() for defaults, metadata. frozen=True for immutability. Use asdict() for serialization. Validation in __post_init__. Inheritance supported. Better than namedtuple for complex data.

Health check endpoint: GET /health returns 200 { status: 'healthy', timestamp, version, dependencies: { db: 'connected', cache: 'connected' } }. Checks critical dependencies. Shallow check by default, ?deep=true for thorough. Used by load balancers, monitoring. Timeout after 5s, return 503.

Go clean architecture: handlers -> services -> repositories. Dependencies point inward. Domain in center, independent. Inject dependencies via constructors. Interfaces in domain, implementations in infrastructure. Use wire or dig for DI. Main package only wires dependencies.

CQRS pattern separation: commands (write) and queries (read) in separate handlers. Command: CreateUser, UpdateUser. Query: GetUser, ListUsers. Different models: WriteModel with behavior, ReadModel optimized for queries. Eventually consistent read models. Event sourcing optional but common pairing.

All Express middleware in this project follows the pattern: async (req, res, next) => { try { ... } catch(err) { next(err); } }. Never call res.send() inside catch blocks - always pass errors to next() for centralized error handling middleware.

Python service classes always use dependency injection via constructor. Pattern: class UserService: def __init__(self, db: Database, cache: Cache). Never instantiate dependencies inside methods. Makes testing way easier.

Auth flow uses JWT access tokens (15min expiry) + refresh tokens (7 days) stored in httpOnly cookies. Access token in Authorization header, refresh endpoint at POST /auth/refresh. Middleware checks both and auto-refreshes when access token expired but refresh valid.

Rust error handling: domain errors are enums implementing std::error::Error. Use thiserror crate. Pattern: #[derive(Error, Debug)] pub enum UserError { #[error("User not found: {0}")] NotFound(UserId) }. Always include context in error variants.

Go repository pattern: interfaces in domain package, implementations in infra. type UserRepo interface { Find(ctx, id) (*User, error) }. Actual postgres/mongo impls live in separate packages. ctx always first param.

TypeScript API responses always wrapped in { data, error, meta } envelope. data is null on error, error is null on success. meta contains pagination/timing info. Type: ApiResponse<T> = { data: T | null; error: string | null; meta?: object }

Test file naming: user.service.test.ts for unit tests, user.service.integration.test.ts for integration tests. Integration tests in separate __integration__ folder. Jest runs unit tests by default, npm run test:integration for full suite.

All async functions in Python use async/await - no mixing callbacks or thread pools. Database operations use asyncpg, HTTP calls use aiohttp. Pattern: async with db.transaction(): await db.execute(...). Always use context managers for transactions.

Module structure: each domain module has types.ts (interfaces/types), service.ts (business logic), repository.ts (data access), controller.ts (HTTP handlers). No circular deps - types can be imported anywhere, services depend on repos, controllers depend on services.

Naming convention: private methods prefixed with underscore. _validateInput(), _buildQuery(). Public methods are verbs: createUser(), fetchOrders(). Boolean properties start with is/has/can: isActive, hasPermission, canEdit.

Rust async pattern: tokio runtime, tokio::spawn for background tasks, join! macro for concurrent operations. Pattern: let (users, orders) = tokio::join!(fetch_users(), fetch_orders()); Always handle JoinError when awaiting spawned tasks.

Error handling middleware stack order matters: 1) CORS, 2) body parsing, 3) request logging, 4) auth middleware, 5) routes, 6) 404 handler, 7) error handler. Error handler must be last with signature (err, req, res, next).

Go context pattern: every function taking >100ms gets ctx context.Context as first param. Use context.WithTimeout for external calls. Pattern: ctx, cancel := context.WithTimeout(ctx, 5*time.Second); defer cancel(). Always defer cancel.

TypeScript discriminated unions for state management: type RequestState = { status: 'idle' } | { status: 'loading' } | { status: 'success'; data: T } | { status: 'error'; error: string }. Switch on status field, TypeScript narrows types automatically.

Python testing uses pytest fixtures for setup. Fixture scope: function for fresh state, session for expensive setup like DB containers. Pattern: @pytest.fixture(scope="session") async def db(): async with AsyncEngine() as engine: yield engine. Always cleanup in fixtures.

API versioning in URL: /api/v1/users, /api/v2/users. Controllers organized by version in folders: v1/, v2/. Breaking changes require new version. Same version must maintain backward compatibility. Version in Accept header rejected - too hard to route.

Rust Result<T, E> usage: use ? operator for propagating errors, unwrap() forbidden outside tests. Pattern: fn process() -> Result<Data, AppError> { let user = repo.find(id)?; Ok(transform(user)) }. Always specify both Ok and Err types explicitly.

Database migrations: sequential numbered files 001_initial.sql, 002_add_users.sql. Never modify existing migrations after deployment. Use migrate up/down commands. Rollback SQL must be in DOWN section. Test rollback before deploying.

TypeScript barrel exports: index.ts re-exports public API of each module. Pattern: export { UserService } from './user.service'; export type { User, UserDTO } from './types'. Internal files start with underscore _internal.ts and aren't exported.

Python dataclasses for DTOs with validation: @dataclass class UserDTO: email: str; age: int; def __post_init__: validate_email(self.email). Use dacite for JSON deserialization. Frozen=True for immutable DTOs passed between layers.

Go table-driven tests: tests := []struct { name string; input X; want Y; wantErr bool }{...}. Loop through with t.Run(tt.name, func(t *testing.T){...}). Gives clear test names in output. Always include edge cases and error scenarios.

Authentication middleware sets req.user = { id, email, roles } after validating JWT. Downstream handlers can assume req.user exists. Protected routes wrapped with requireAuth middleware. Pattern: router.get('/profile', requireAuth, profileController).

Async task queue pattern: user requests return 202 Accepted with taskId, client polls GET /tasks/:id for status. Task handler updates task state in Redis: pending -> running -> completed/failed. Include result/error in task record. 24hr retention.

TypeScript utility types pattern: Omit for removing fields (Omit<User, 'password'>), Pick for selecting fields, Partial for optional, Required for mandatory. Type CreateUserDTO = Omit<User, 'id' | 'createdAt'>. Define reusable types, don't inline everywhere.

Rust builder pattern for complex objects: UserBuilder::new().email(e).name(n).build(). Builder validates on build(), returns Result. Pattern: pub struct UserBuilder { email: Option<String> }; impl UserBuilder { pub fn build(self) -> Result<User, BuildError> }.

Python repository methods return domain objects, not ORM models. Pattern: class UserRepo: async def find(id) -> Optional[User]: row = await db.fetch_one(...); return User.from_row(row) if row else None. Keeps domain layer clean from SQLAlchemy/Django ORM.

Logging convention: structured JSON logs. Fields: timestamp, level, message, requestId, userId, duration. Use correlation IDs across services. Pattern: logger.info('user.created', { userId, email, requestId }). Never log sensitive data like passwords/tokens.

Go interface segregation: small focused interfaces. type Reader interface { Read() }; type Writer interface { Write() }. Combine when needed: type ReadWriter interface { Reader; Writer }. Makes mocking easier - mock only what you need.

TypeScript React hooks convention: custom hooks start with 'use'. useUser(), useFetchData(). Extract to hooks/ folder when reused. Pattern: function useUser() { const [user, setUser] = useState(); useEffect(() => {...}, []); return { user, loading, error }; }

Database connection pooling: min 5, max 20 connections. Connection timeout 30s, idle timeout 10min. Use PgBouncer in transaction mode for serverless. Pattern: pool = Pool(min_size=5, max_size=20, max_inactive_connection_lifetime=600). Monitor with pool.get_size().

Rust option combinators over explicit matching: use .map(), .and_then(), .unwrap_or() instead of match Some/None everywhere. Pattern: user.email.as_ref().map(|e| e.to_lowercase()).unwrap_or_default(). More concise and idiomatic.

API rate limiting: Redis-backed token bucket. 100 req/min per API key, 1000 req/hour. Middleware checks and decrements tokens. Response headers: X-RateLimit-Remaining, X-RateLimit-Reset. Return 429 with Retry-After header when exceeded.

Python dependency injection with dependency-injector: Container class holds all services. Pattern: class Container(containers.DeclarativeContainer): db = providers.Singleton(Database); user_service = providers.Factory(UserService, db=db). Wire to FastAPI with Depends().

Go error wrapping: use fmt.Errorf with %w verb to wrap errors. Pattern: if err != nil { return fmt.Errorf("failed to fetch user: %w", err) }. Preserves error chain for errors.Is/As. Never return err directly - add context.

TypeScript branded types for IDs: type UserId = string & { __brand: 'UserId' }; const toUserId = (id: string): UserId => id as UserId. Prevents mixing different ID types. Function signatures: function getUser(id: UserId) - can't pass OrderId by mistake.

Testing strategy: unit tests mock all external deps (DB, APIs), integration tests use testcontainers for real DB, E2E tests hit deployed staging env. 80% unit, 15% integration, 5% E2E. CI runs all, local dev runs unit by default.

Rust trait objects for plugin systems: Box<dyn Trait> for single ownership, Arc<dyn Trait> for shared. Pattern: trait MessageHandler: Send + Sync { fn handle(&self, msg: &Message) -> Result<()> }. Send + Sync required for thread safety.

Config management: environment-specific files (config.dev.json, config.prod.json). Load based on NODE_ENV. Never commit secrets - use env vars for sensitive values. Pattern: const config = { ...baseConfig, ...envConfig, ...{ apiKey: process.env.API_KEY } }.

Python async context managers for resource cleanup: async with ResourcePool() as resource: await resource.use(). Pattern: class DBConnection: async def __aenter__(self): self.conn = await connect(); return self.conn; async def __aexit__(self, *args): await self.conn.close().

Go package naming: short, lowercase, no underscores. Package name should be singular noun (user not users). Avoid stutter: user.User not user.UserModel. Import path reflects purpose: internal/domain/user, internal/infra/postgres.

TypeScript exhaustiveness checking with never: function handle(state: State) { switch(state.status) { case 'idle': ...; case 'loading': ...; default: const _exhaustive: never = state; throw new Error(_exhaustive); }. Forces handling all union cases.

Pagination pattern: cursor-based for infinite scroll, offset-based for page numbers. Cursor encodes last item ID + timestamp. Response: { items: [], nextCursor: string | null, hasMore: boolean }. Limit max page size to 100. Default to 20.

Rust newtype pattern for domain primitives: struct Email(String); impl Email { pub fn new(s: String) -> Result<Self> { validate_email(&s)?; Ok(Email(s)) } }. Can't create invalid Email. Use Deref for transparent access to inner string.

Python factory pattern for object creation: class UserFactory: @staticmethod def create_from_dict(data: dict) -> User: return User(id=data['id'], ...). Centralizes object construction logic. Easy to add validation or transformations. Used in tests with fixtures.

Middleware composition: compose([cors, logging, auth, ratelimit]) creates single handler. Each middleware calls next() to continue chain or returns early to short-circuit. Order matters - auth after logging so failed auth is logged.

Go channels for worker pools: jobs := make(chan Job, 100); for range numWorkers { go worker(jobs) }. Send jobs to channel, workers process concurrently. Use WaitGroup to wait for completion. Pattern: var wg sync.WaitGroup; wg.Add(n); ...; wg.Wait().

TypeScript module augmentation for extending libraries: declare module 'express-serve-static-core' { interface Request { user?: User; requestId: string } }. Adds type-safe fields to third-party types. Put in types/express.d.ts, reference in tsconfig.

Background job processing: Celery for Python, Bull for Node. Tasks must be idempotent - retry on failure. Store task metadata for debugging. Pattern: @celery.task(bind=True, max_retries=3) def process_order(self, order_id): try: ... except SoftError as e: raise self.retry(exc=e, countdown=60).

Rust type state pattern: struct Locked; struct Unlocked; struct Door<State> { state: PhantomData<State> }. Methods only on specific states: impl Door<Locked> { fn unlock(self) -> Door<Unlocked> }. Compile-time state machine. Can't call wrong method on wrong state.

Feature flags: stored in config service, cached locally for 5min. Check flag before new code paths. Pattern: if (featureFlags.isEnabled('new-checkout', userId)) { ... } else { ... }. Gradual rollout by percentage or user IDs. Clean up flags after full rollout.

All middleware functions in the Express app follow pattern: export as named function taking (req, res, next), call next() on success, throw AppError on failure. ErrorHandler middleware catches all AppErrors and formats response. Example: validateAuth, checkPermissions, parseBody.

Python services use Result[T, E] pattern from returns library. Never raise exceptions for expected errors. Service methods return Success(value) or Failure(error). Controllers unwrap Results and map to HTTP responses. Exceptions only for truly unexpected errors.

Auth flow: JWT in httpOnly cookie named 'auth_token'. Middleware extracts token, verifies with public key, attaches user object to req.user. Refresh token stored separately in 'refresh_token' cookie. Access token expires 15min, refresh 7days.

Test files named *.test.ts, located in __tests__ directory adjacent to source. Each test file mirrors source structure. Use describe blocks for grouping by method/function. beforeEach for setup, afterEach for cleanup. Mock external dependencies using jest.mock().

Rust error handling: define AppError enum with variants for each error category. Implement From<T> for converting library errors. Use ? operator throughout. Main function returns Result<(), AppError>. Error messages include context using .context() from anyhow.

TypeScript naming: interfaces prefixed with I (IUser, IProduct). Types suffixed with Type (ResponseType). Enums in PascalCase. Constants in SCREAMING_SNAKE_CASE. Private class members prefixed with underscore (_userId).

Go project structure: /cmd for main applications, /internal for private code, /pkg for public libraries, /api for API definitions (OpenAPI/protobuf). Each package in single directory. Avoid deep nesting beyond 3 levels.

Async patterns in Node: use async/await exclusively, no raw promises or callbacks. Wrap external callbacks with util.promisify. For parallel operations use Promise.all(). For sequential with shared state use for...of loop with await.

Repository pattern: each entity gets a repository class with methods: findById, findMany, create, update, delete. Repositories inject database connection via constructor. Return domain models, not raw DB results. Keep DB logic encapsulated.

Python type hints: use from __future__ import annotations for forward references. All public functions fully typed. Use Protocol for structural typing. Generic types with TypeVar. Use | for unions (str | None) instead of Optional.

Environment variables: load using dotenv at app startup. Define schema using Zod/io-ts to validate required vars. Store parsed config in frozen object exported from config.ts. Never access process.env directly outside config module.

GraphQL resolvers: each resolver file corresponds to type in schema. Resolvers receive (parent, args, context, info). Context contains dataloaders, current user, request. Use dataloader pattern to batch/cache database queries.

Rust module structure: lib.rs exports public API. Private modules in separate files. Use pub(crate) for internal-only items. Group related functionality in submodules. Re-export important types at crate root for ergonomics.

Error responses: standard format { error: { code: string, message: string, details?: any } }. Code is UPPER_SNAKE_CASE matching error type. Message is human-readable. Details for validation errors contains field-level info.

Database migrations: sequentially numbered YYYYMMDDHHMMSS_description.sql files. Up and down migrations in same file separated by -- +goose Up comment. Never edit existing migrations, only add new ones. Run in transaction by default.

React hooks conventions: custom hooks prefixed with 'use'. Extract component logic to hooks when reused 2+ times. Hooks return tuple [state, actions] or object { data, loading, error, refetch }. Keep hooks pure, side effects in useEffect.

Go error wrapping: use fmt.Errorf with %w verb to wrap errors. Preserve error chain for debugging. Check specific errors with errors.Is() and errors.As(). Top-level handlers log full chain, return sanitized message to client.

Factory pattern for test fixtures: createUser(), createProduct() functions that accept partial objects and fill defaults. Use faker for random but deterministic data. Export factories from test-utils. Each factory returns saved entity.

TypeScript branded types: type UserId = string & { __brand: 'UserId' }. Helper function asUserId(id: string): UserId casts safely. Prevents mixing different ID types. Use for domain identifiers to catch errors at compile time.

Middleware ordering matters: cors -> helmet -> requestId -> logging -> authentication -> authorization -> routes -> errorHandler. Request ID must be early for trace logging. Error handler must be last to catch everything.

Python decorators for cross-cutting: @require_auth, @rate_limit, @cache. Stack decorators bottom-up (inner to outer execution). Auth decorator checks token, attaches user to function via kwargs. Use functools.wraps to preserve metadata.

Pagination standard: accept page (1-indexed) and limit params. Return { data: [], page, limit, total, hasMore }. Default limit 20, max 100. For cursor-based use { data: [], nextCursor, hasMore }. Cursor is opaque base64 string.

Rust builder pattern: struct FooBuilder with methods that consume self and return Self. Build() method consumes builder, validates, returns Result<Foo, ValidationError>. Required fields enforced via type state pattern.

Integration tests: separate from unit tests, in /tests directory. Use testcontainers for database. Each test gets fresh DB via migrations. Real HTTP requests via supertest. Run with --runInBand to avoid port conflicts.

API versioning: /api/v1, /api/v2 URL prefixes. Each version is separate Express router. Share code via internal packages. Deprecate old versions with sunset header. Version in Accept header rejected - too complex for clients.

Logger pattern: inject logger into constructors, don't import globally. Use structured logging with context fields. Log levels: error (requires action), warn (should investigate), info (significant events), debug (detailed trace).

Go context usage: first parameter of every function that does I/O. Use context.WithTimeout for external calls. Pass request context through entire chain. Store request-scoped values (user, trace ID) in context with typed keys.

TypeScript discriminated unions for state: type LoadingState = { status: 'loading' } | { status: 'success', data: T } | { status: 'error', error: Error }. Switch on status field, TypeScript narrows type automatically.

Validation layer: use Zod schemas for all input validation (API requests, env vars, external data). Define schema adjacent to type. Use .parse() to throw, .safeParse() to handle errors. Share schemas between frontend/backend.

Event-driven: emit domain events from services using EventEmitter pattern. Events named PAST_TENSE (USER_CREATED, ORDER_PLACED). Handlers in separate modules. Async handlers must not block main flow - queue to background job.

Python async: use asyncio for I/O-bound operations. Database access via asyncpg/motor. HTTP via httpx. Never mix sync/async - use asyncio.run() at top level only. Use async context managers for resource cleanup.

Dependency injection: services receive dependencies via constructor. Use InversifyJS container configured in composition root. Bind interfaces to implementations. Request-scoped bindings for current user. Avoid service locator pattern.

File uploads: accept multipart/form-data, stream to S3 using multer-s3. Generate unique key: {userId}/{timestamp}-{uuid}.{ext}. Return signed URL for access. Validate file type via magic numbers, not extension. 10MB max size.

Rust traits for abstraction: define trait for behavior (UserRepository). Implement for concrete types (PostgresUserRepository). Functions accept impl Trait or Box<dyn Trait>. Use trait objects for runtime polymorphism.
Rate limiting: Redis-backed token bucket per IP and per user. IP limit: 100/min. Authenticated user: 1000/min. Return 429 with Retry-After header. Exclude health check endpoint from limiting.

Background jobs: use Bull queue with Redis. Job data typed with interfaces. Processors in /jobs directory. Configure retry with exponential backoff. Implement idempotency - jobs safe to run multiple times.

Go testing: table-driven tests with subtests. Define []struct with name, input, expected. Use t.Run() for each case. Parallel execution with t.Parallel() when no shared state. Mocks via interfaces, generated with mockery.

API documentation: OpenAPI spec generated from code using tsoa decorators. Controllers annotated with @Route, @Get, @Post. Response types define schema. Example values in JSDoc. Serve Swagger UI at /api-docs.

Transaction handling: use database transaction for multi-step operations. Pass transaction object through call chain. Rollback on any error. For distributed transactions use saga pattern with compensation.

TypeScript utility types: Partial<T> for optional updates, Pick<T, K> for subsets, Omit<T, K> to exclude fields. Define domain types strict, derive API types: type CreateUserDto = Omit<User, 'id' | 'createdAt'>.

Health checks: /health returns 200 with { status: 'ok', timestamp, version }. /health/ready checks dependencies (DB, Redis, external APIs). Kubernetes readiness probe hits /health/ready. Liveness hits /health.

Python dataclasses for DTOs: @dataclass decorator with frozen=True. Use dataclasses.asdict() for serialization. Define from_dict classmethod for deserialization. Validation in __post_init__. Use slots=True for memory efficiency.

CQRS pattern: separate read and write models. Commands (write) go through service layer with validation. Queries (read) bypass service, go directly to specialized query handlers. Different database schemas for read/write.

Rust ownership patterns: take ownership with owned value, borrow with &T for read, &mut T for write. Return owned values from constructors. Accept borrows in methods. Clone only when necessary, prefer references.

WebSocket handling: separate WS server from HTTP. Authenticate via token in initial handshake. Store connection->user mapping in Redis. Broadcast to rooms using pub/sub. Heartbeat every 30s, disconnect if no pong.

Code organization: feature-based folders over type-based. Each feature module contains models, service, controller, types, tests. Shared code in /common. Avoid circular dependencies - extract shared types to separate module.
Go interfaces: keep interfaces small (1-3 methods). Define interfaces where they're used (consumer), not where implemented. Accept interfaces, return structs. Use embedding for composition.

Cache strategy: Redis for session and frequently-accessed data. TTL based on data volatility: user sessions 1hr, product catalog 5min. Cache aside pattern: check cache, on miss fetch from DB and set cache.

TypeScript const assertions: use 'as const' for literal types. Define route constants as const ROUTES = { ... } as const. Enables type inference from values. Export types via typeof: export type Route = typeof ROUTES[keyof typeof ROUTES].

Security headers: helmet middleware sets CSP, HSTS, X-Frame-Options. CORS configured with whitelist of allowed origins from config. Sanitize user input with DOMPurify. Parameterized queries prevent SQL injection. bcrypt for password hashing (cost 12).
I prefer 2-space indentation for JavaScript and TypeScript, but 4 spaces for Python. Never use tabs.
Always use trailing commas in JavaScript objects and arrays. It makes diffs cleaner.
I prefer functional programming style over OOP when possible. Use pure functions, avoid classes unless absolutely necessary.
For error handling in Node.js, I prefer explicit try-catch blocks over error-first callbacks. Always wrap await calls in try-catch.
I like single quotes for strings in JavaScript, but double quotes in Python. Be consistent within each language.
Write test descriptions in natural language using 'should' statements, like 'should return 404 when user not found'.
I prefer named exports over default exports in TypeScript modules. Makes refactoring easier.
Always add JSDoc comments for public functions, but skip them for private/internal functions unless the logic is complex.
I use conventional commits format: feat:, fix:, docs:, refactor:, test:, chore:. Keep the first line under 50 characters.
For git workflow, I prefer feature branches with descriptive names like 'feature/user-authentication' or 'fix/memory-leak-in-parser'.
I always rebase feature branches on main before merging to keep a linear history. Avoid merge commits when possible.
In code reviews, I care most about readability and maintainability. Flag unclear variable names and missing error handling.
I prefer async/await over promise chains. It's more readable and easier to debug.
Use early returns to avoid deep nesting. If there's an error condition, return immediately rather than wrapping everything in else blocks.
I like co-locating tests with source files in __tests__ directories rather than having a separate top-level tests folder.
For API responses, I prefer explicit error objects with 'error' and 'message' fields over throwing HTTP exceptions directly.
I use Prettier with default settings except printWidth: 100. Run it on save automatically.
Prefer const over let, and never use var in JavaScript. Only use let when reassignment is actually needed.
I like destructuring imports, like 'const { Router } = require('express')' rather than importing the whole module.
For environment variables, I use a .env file locally and prefer a config module that validates all required vars at startup.
I prefer integration tests over unit tests for most features. Test the behavior, not the implementation.
Use meaningful variable names even if they're longer. Avoid abbreviations unless they're widely known (like 'err', 'req', 'res').
I prefer explicit type annotations in TypeScript function signatures, even when they could be inferred.
For database queries, I prefer using query builders like Knex over raw SQL strings. Easier to maintain and less SQL injection risk.
I use VS Code with Vim keybindings. I navigate mostly with keyboard shortcuts and rarely use the mouse.
Prefer optional chaining (?.) and nullish coalescing (??) operators over manual null checks in modern JavaScript.
I like keeping functions small - ideally under 20 lines. If it's longer, it probably should be split up.
For logging, I use structured logging with JSON format in production. Include request IDs to trace requests across services.
I prefer interface over type in TypeScript for object shapes. Save type for unions and complex types.
Always add a README with setup instructions, environment variables needed, and how to run tests for each project.
I like using enums or constant objects for status codes and magic strings rather than having them scattered throughout the code.
For React components, I prefer functional components with hooks over class components. Keep components small and focused.
I prefer Zsh with Oh My Zsh and the 'robbyrussell' theme. I have aliases for common git commands like 'gco' for checkout.
Use guard clauses at the start of functions to validate inputs and handle edge cases before the main logic.
I prefer dependency injection over importing modules directly when it makes sense. Makes testing much easier.
For CSS, I prefer utility-first frameworks like Tailwind over writing custom CSS. Keep styling co-located with components.
I like using factory functions or fixtures for test data rather than manually creating objects in each test.
Prefer Array methods like map, filter, reduce over for loops when working with collections. More declarative and functional.
I use ESLint with Airbnb config as a base, but disable rules about underscore-dangle and no-console for dev environments.
For git commits, I prefer small, atomic commits that each do one thing over large commits that mix multiple changes.
I like adding TODO comments with my initials and date like '// TODO(jsmith 2024-01-15): Refactor this to use async/await'.
Prefer composition over inheritance. If you're using 'extends', think about whether composition would work better.
I use tmux for terminal multiplexing with custom keybindings. Prefix is Ctrl-a instead of Ctrl-b.
For package management, I prefer pnpm over npm or yarn. It's faster and handles disk space better with symlinks.
I like using absolute imports with path aliases (like '@/components') rather than relative imports with lots of '../..'.
Prefer explicit boolean comparisons like 'if (value === true)' over implicit ones like 'if (value)' when the distinction matters.
I always add .editorconfig files to projects to ensure consistent formatting across different editors and team members.
For error messages, I prefer being specific and actionable. Say what went wrong and what the user should do, not just 'Error occurred'.
I prefer immutable data patterns. Use spread operators or Object.assign to create new objects rather than mutating existing ones.
For monorepos, I prefer using workspaces with pnpm or Yarn rather than Lerna. Simpler and more maintainable.
I prefer 2-space indentation for JavaScript and TypeScript, but 4 spaces for Python. Never use tabs.

I prefer functional programming patterns over classes whenever possible. Use pure functions and avoid side effects.

I like to use early returns to avoid nested if statements. Guard clauses at the top of functions are my preference.
